reference: Volume Four, Issue Forty-Three, File 16 of 27
title: AT$T 5ESS(tm) From Top to Bottom
short_summary: This article provides an in-depth look at the architecture, hardware, and software of the AT&T 5ESS switch, detailing its components and programming techniques. It also discusses the implications of accessing and manipulating the switch's functionalities.
summary:
The article delves into the architecture of the AT&T 5ESS switch, a digital switching system that utilizes a Time Space Time (TST) topology. It outlines the major components, including the Administrative Module and Communications Module, detailing their functions and interconnections. The author emphasizes the switch's modular design and distributed control, which contribute to its efficiency and speed compared to other systems like the DMS 100. The article also highlights the UNIX-based software that underpins the 5ESS, explaining how it has evolved from earlier systems and the significance of its command structure.

In addition to the technical specifications, the article touches on the ethical considerations of programming the switch, warning against malicious activities that could disrupt emergency services like 911. The author provides practical commands for accessing various functionalities of the switch, including the Recent Change and Verify (RC/V) channels, and emphasizes the importance of understanding the system's operations to avoid unintended consequences. Overall, this piece serves as both a technical guide and a cautionary tale for those interested in telecommunications and switch programming.
